initial_version:
The Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine was particuarlized as an independent denomination on April 16th, 2008.  At the time of particuarlization, 8 fully fledged Presbyterian Churches were active across Ukraine.

Partner Organizations include the 
The Evangelical Reformed Seminary of Ukraine[http://evrefsem.com/cross/]
and Mission to The World [http://www.mtwukraine.org/index.php?option=com_wrapper&Itemid=71]
Churches within the denomination include: Nikolayev church [http://nikchurch.narod.ru/]
Izmail Church [http://www.mtwukraine.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=21&Itemid=74],
	Odessa Church [http://www.odessachurch.org]
Solomensky Reformed Presbyterian Church [http://www.sprchurch.org.ua/]
Belgorod Church [http://www.christianclinic.org/cgi-bin/clinic.cgi?category=300&]
Kharkov Church [http://www.kharkov-church.narod.ru/]
Kherson Church [http://www.mtwukraine.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=21&Itemid=74]
	Holy Trinity Church [http://holytrinity.inet-ua.ws/index-eng.htm]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -13,3 +13,4 @@
 	The Presbyterian Church of the Holy Trinity (Kiev) [http://holytrinity.inet-ua.ws/index-eng.htm]
 
 [[Category: Christianity-related_lists]]
+[[Category: Presbyterian denominations]]
llm_output:
Added a category tag for "Presbyterian denominations".

Not Weaponised – The change is a simple categorization addition that does not carry any political or cultural implications.

--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,11 +1,26 @@
 {{Refimprove|date=December 2010}}
+== Origin ==
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination comprised one presbytery and 3 organised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the Presbyterian Church in America in the early 1990s. The bigest congregation is in Kiev, Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church ,the attendance is over 500 people in a week. There are congregations in 9 various cities.
 
-The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received it's 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the Communist times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in 5 various cities.This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]
+== History ==
+It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s canadian-ukrainian missionairies revitalised the Reformed faith. There was 35 churches and approximately 3000 members. After the Worl War II. the Communist regime destroyed much of this work.
+The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received it's 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the Communist times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in 5 various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]
 
+== Missions ==
 The church has newly opened missions, outreaches in Western Ukraine and in other parts of the country. New groups are gathering in Zaphoroze and in Cherkassy.The goal is to have 44 presbyterian churches in Ukraine within 15 years.
 
+== Reformed Seminary in Ukraine ==
 A reformed seminary The Evangelical Reformed Church in Ukraine was opened to train pastors and officers.M.Div classes begun in 2000 with 20 students.In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from Canada, USA, The Nethertlands, and South Africa.
+
+== Theology ==

 == History ==
 It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s canadian-ukrainian missionairies revitalised the Reformed faith in western Ukraine wich was then occupied by Poland. There was 35 churches and approximately 3000 members. After the Worl War II. the Communist regime destroyed much of this work.
-
+After breaking-up the Soviet Union short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. Church planting team to sheperd the forming religious communities.
 The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received it's 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the Communist times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in 5 various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today] The Evangelical Presbyterian church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.
 
 The Belgorod Christian Chlinic is a ministry of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Belgorod - Dnestrovsky. The Belgorod presbyterian church was the first local church planted by MTW missionaries in Ukraine.

+The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination comprised one presbytery and 3 organised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the Presbyterian Church in America in the early 1990s. The biggest congregation is in Kiev, Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church, the attendance is over 500 people in a week. There are congregations in 9 various cities.
 
 == History ==
 It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian-Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in western Ukraine which was then occupied by Poland. There were 35 churches and approximately 3000 members. After the World War II. the Communist regime destroyed much of this work.
 
 After breaking-up the Soviet Union short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. Church planting team to shepherd the forming religious communities.
-The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received its 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the Communist times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today] The Evangelical Presbyterian church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.
+The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received its 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the Communist times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-volume-1-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today] The Evangelical Presbyterian church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.
 
 The Belgorod Christian Clinic is a ministry of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Belgorod - Dnestrovsky. The Belgorod Presbyterian Church was the first local church planted by MTW missionaries in Ukraine.

M.Div classes begun in 2000 with 20 students.In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from Canada, USA, The Nethertlands, and South Africa.

+{{Refimprove|date=December 2010}}The Evangelical Presbyterian Church  in Ukraine is a conservative evangelical denomination in the [[Reformed]] Calvinistic tradition. [[Presbyterian]] government and Covenant theology 5 points of [[Calvinism]].
 
 == Origin ==
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination comprised one presbytery and 3 organised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. The biggest congregation is in [[Kiev]], Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church, the attendance is over 500 people in a week. There are congregations in 9 various cities.
 
 == History ==
-It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian-Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. There were 35 churches and approximately 3000 members. After the World War II. the Communist regime destroyed much of this work.
+It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.
 
 After breaking-up the [[Soviet Union]] short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. Church planting team to shepherd the forming religious communities.
-The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received its 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the [[Communist]] times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. --- 
+++ 
@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination comprised one presbytery and 3 organised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. The biggest congregation is in [[Kiev]], Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church, the attendance is over 500 people in a week. There are congregations in 9 various cities.
 
 == History ==
-It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian-Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. There were 35 churches and approximately 3000 members. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.
+It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]].Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]] there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
 After breaking-up the [[Soviet Union]] short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. Church planting team to shepherd the forming religious communities.
 The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received its 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the [[Communist]] times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>
llm_output:

Not Weaponised – The changes provide historical context about the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Ukraine without employing language that could be seen as politically charged or weaponizing cultural narratives.

+The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprised of 3 particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>[http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html]</ref>
 
 == History ==
 It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]] there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors.  The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination comprised one presbytery and 3 organised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. The biggest congregation is in [[Kiev]], Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church, the attendance is over 500 people in a week. There are congregations in 9 various cities.
 
 == History ==
-It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]].Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]] there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
+It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]] there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
 After breaking-up the [[Soviet Union]] short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. Church planting team to shepherd the forming religious communities.
 The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received its 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the [[Communist]] times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>

+++ 
@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 {{Refimprove|date=December 2010}}The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Ukraine is a conservative evangelical denomination in the [[Reformed]] tradition. It holds to a [[Presbyterian]] form of government and to the Reformed theology of the Westminster Standards.<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net www.reformiert-online.net]</ref>
 
 == Origin ==
-The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprised of 3 particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>[http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html]</ref>
+The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>[http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html]</ref>
 
 == History ==
 It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]] there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
llm_output:
Changed "comprised of" to "comprising" in the context of the description of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine.

Not Weaponised – The change is a grammatical correction that does not alter the meaning or introduce any politically charged language.

 == Origin ==
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation.  The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' is a conservative evangelical denomination in the [[Reformed]] tradition. It holds to a [[Presbyterian]] form of government and to the Reformed theology of the Westminster Standards.<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net www.reformiert-online.net]</ref>
 
 == Origin ==
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>[http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html]</ref>
 
 == History ==
-It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]] there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
+It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
 After breaking-up the [[Soviet Union]] short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. Church planting team to shepherd the forming religious communities.
 The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received its 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the [[Communist]] times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>[http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html]</ref>
 
 == History ==
-It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
+It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter Sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
 After breaking-up the [[Soviet Union]] short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. Church planting team to shepherd the forming religious communities.
 The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received its 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the [[Communist]] times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref><ref>http://swanson4ukraine.wordpress.com/tag/evangelical-presbyterian-reformed-church-of-odessa/</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>
@@ -25,7 +25,7 @@
 The Belgorod Christian Clinic is a ministry of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in [[Belgorod-Dnestrovsky]]. The Belgorod Presbyterian Church was the first local church planted by MTW missionaries in Ukraine.
 
 == Missions ==
-The church has missions churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kiyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], [[Kharkov]]. The first outreach to the western part of [[Ukraine]] is the new Lviv church plant. In the town there are a cross-cultural church planting team, trying to built relationship to the peolpe, through English ministry, mercy ministry.<ref>http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>
+The church has missions churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kiyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], [[Kharkov]]. The first outreach to the western part of [[Ukraine]] is the new Lviv church plant. In the town there are a cross-cultural church planting team, trying to built relationship to the people, through English ministry, mercy ministry.<ref>http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>
 
 == Reformed Seminary in Ukraine ==
 A reformed seminary The Evangelical Reformed Seminary of Ukraine was opened to train pastors and officers. M.Div classes begun in 2000 with 20 students. In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology classes are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from [[Canada]], the [[United States]], the [[Netherlands]], and [[South Africa]].<ref>[http://www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/history www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/history]</ref>

It holds to a [[Presbyterian]] form of government and to the Reformed theology of the Westminster Standards.<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net www.reformiert-online.net]</ref>
 
 == Origin ==
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>[http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html]</ref>

@@ -19,13 +19,13 @@
 == History ==
 It's a little known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter Sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomya]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
-After breaking-up the [[Soviet Union]] short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. Church planting team to shepherd the forming religious communities.
-The church in Odessa was first particularized in the history of the whole denomination. The Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa received its 100 years old historic building in 1998. In the past the church community had been disbanded and the building was taken in the [[Communist]] times and converted to a puppet house, and later abandoned. The church building had been renovated by the church. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. The weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. This has become a center for church planter in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref><ref>http://swanson4ukraine.wordpress.com/tag/evangelical-presbyterian-reformed-church-of-odessa/</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>
+After the break up of the [[Soviet Union]], short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. They formed church planting teams to shepherd the forming religious communities.
+The church in Odessa was the first church to be particularized in the history of the denomination. In 1998, the Ukrainian government granted the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa the 100 year old historic building that had housed a reformed congregation before the advent of communist restrictions to religious practise. During [[Communist]] times, the building had been seized and turned into a puppet theater. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. Upon regaining possesion of the building, the Presbyterian Church renovated it and installed an organ.  Weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. It has become a center for church planters in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref><ref>http://swanson4ukraine.wordpress.com/tag/evangelical-presbyterian-reformed-church-of-odessa/</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>
 
 The Belgorod Christian Clinic is a ministry of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in [[Belgorod-Dnestrovsky]]. The Belgorod Presbyterian Church was the first local church planted by MTW missionaries in Ukraine.
 
 == Missions ==
-The church has missions churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kiyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], [[Kharkov]]. The first outreach to the western part of [[Ukraine]] is the new Lviv church plant. In the town there are a cross-cultural church planting team, trying to built relationship to the people, through English ministry, mercy ministry.<ref>http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>
+The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kiyiv|Kyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], [[Kharkov]]. The first outreach to the western part of [[Ukraine]] is the new Lviv church plant. In the town there are a cross-cultural church planting team, trying to built relationship to the people, through English ministry, mercy ministry.<ref>http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>
 
 == Reformed Seminary in Ukraine ==
 A reformed seminary The Evangelical Reformed Seminary of Ukraine was opened to train pastors and officers. M.Div classes begun in 2000 with 20 students. In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology classes are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from [[Canada]], the [[United States]], the [[Netherlands]], and [[South Africa]].<ref>[http://www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/history www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/history]</ref>
comment: /* Missions */  edits for grammar and flow
llm_output:

- Rephrased sentences for clarity and flow, such as changing "After breaking-up the [[Soviet Union]] short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities." to "After the break up of the [[Soviet Union]], short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities."
- Added context regarding the historical significance of the church building in Odessa, emphasizing its prior use and the impact of communist restrictions.

**Weaponised**: The revision subtly emphasizes the historical context of the church's building and its significance in relation to the communist regime, which could be interpreted as a narrative that highlights the oppression faced by religious communities under Soviet rule. This framing can serve to reinforce a narrative of cultural and religious resilience against past oppression, which may be weaponized in discussions about current cultural heritage and identity.

Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Coloma, Ukraine|Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
+It's a little-known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter Sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomyia]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Coloma, Ukraine|Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
 After the break up of the [[Soviet Union]], short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. They formed church planting teams to shepherd the forming religious communities.
 The church in Odessa was the first church to be particularized in the history of the denomination. In 1998, the Ukrainian government granted the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa the 100-year-old historic building that had housed a reformed congregation before the advent of communist restrictions to religious practise. During [[Communist]] times, the building had been seized and turned into a puppet theater. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. Upon regaining possession of the building, the Presbyterian Church renovated it and installed an organ.  Weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. It has become a center for church planters in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref><ref>http://swanson4ukraine.wordpress.com/tag/evangelical-presbyterian-reformed-church-of-odessa/</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>

 == Missions ==
-The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kiyiv|Kyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], and [[Kherson]]. The first outreach to [[Western Ukraine]] is taking place through the Lviv church plant. In that beautiful city there is an international, cross-cultural church planting team that is building relationships with people, including through English and mercy ministries.<ref>http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. In that beautiful city there is an international, cross-cultural church planting team that is building relationships with people, including through English and mercy ministries.<ref>http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>
 
 == Reformed Seminary in Ukraine ==
 A reformed seminary The Evangelical Reformed Seminary of Ukraine was opened to train pastors and officers. M.Div classes begun in 2000 with 20 students. In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology classes are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from [[Canada]], the [[United States]], the [[Netherlands]], [[South Africa]] and the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>[http://www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/history www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/history]</ref>

-The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' is a [[Christian fundamentalism|conservative]] [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denomination in the [[Calvinism|Reformed tradition]]. It holds to a [[presbyterian polity|presbyterian]] form of [[ecclesiastical polity|church governance]] and to the English Reformed theology of the [[Westminster Standards]].<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net www.reformiert-online.net]</ref>
+The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' is a [[Christian fundamentalism|conservative]] [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denomination in the [[Calvinism|Reformed tradition]]. It holds to a [[presbyterian polity|presbyterian]] form of [[ecclesiastical polity|church governance]] and to the Reformed theology of the [[Westminster Standards]].<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net www.reformiert-online.net]</ref>
 
 == Origin ==
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>[http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html]</ref>
 
 == History ==
-It's a little-known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then occupied by [[Poland]]. They established the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. On Easter Sunday 1925 the first Reformed worship was held in [[Kolomyia]]. Separate German Reformed and Lurheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the presbyterian path the " Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Coloma, Ukraine|Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
+It's a little-known fact that the Reformation came this far eastward, approximately 100 Reformed churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian - Ukrainian missionaries revitalised the Reformed faith in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then part of [[Poland]].  Separate German Reformed and Lutheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and Helvetic Confession - joined the "Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Coloma, Ukraine|Coloma]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Pzemysl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After the World War II. the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
 After the break up of the [[Soviet Union]], short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. They formed church planting teams to shepherd the forming religious communities.
 The church in Odessa was the first church to be particularized in the history of the denomination. In 1998, the Ukrainian government granted the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa the 100-year-old historic building that had housed a reformed congregation before the advent of communist restrictions to religious practise. During [[Communist]] times, the building had been seized and turned into a puppet theater. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. Upon regaining possession of the building, the Presbyterian Church renovated it and installed an organ.  Weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. It has become a center for church planters in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref><ref>http://swanson4ukraine.wordpress.com/tag/evangelical-presbyterian-reformed-church-of-odessa/</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organised at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>
@@ -25,11 +25,11 @@

 == Missions ==
-The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kiyiv|Kyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], [[Kharkov]]. The first outreach to the western part of [[Ukraine]] is the new Lviv church plant. In the town there are a cross-cultural church planting team, trying to built relationship to the people, through English ministry, mercy ministry.<ref>http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>

@@ -12,7 +12,7 @@
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' is a [[Christian fundamentalism|conservative]] [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denomination in the [[Calvinism|Reformed tradition]]. It holds to the [[presbyterian polity|presbyterian]] form of [[ecclesiastical polity|church governance]] and to the Reformed theology of the [[Westminster Standards]].<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net www.reformiert-online.net]</ref>
 
 == Origin ==
-The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |title=www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617113344/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |archive-date=2013-06-17 |dead-url=yes }}</ref>
+The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |title=www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617113344/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |archive-date=2013-06-17 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
 
 == History ==
 It's a little-known fact that the [[Reformation]] came this far eastward, approximately 100 [[Reformed]] churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian-Ukrainian missionaries revitalized the [[Reformed faith]] in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then part of [[Poland]].  Separate German Reformed and Lutheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and [[Helvetic Confession]] - joined the "Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Kolomyia]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Przemyśl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After [[World War II]] the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
@@ -23,7 +23,7 @@
 The Belgorod Christian Clinic is a ministry of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in [[Belgorod-Dnestrovsky]]. The Belgorod Presbyterian Church was the first local church planted by MTW missionaries in Ukraine.
 
 == Missions ==
-The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kiyiv|Kyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], and [[Kherson]]. The first outreach to [[Western Ukraine]] is taking place through the Lviv church plant. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>

After [[World War II]] the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
+It's a little-known fact that the [[Reformation]] came this far eastward, approximately 100 [[Reformed church|Reformed]] churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian-Ukrainian missionaries revitalized the [[Reformed faith]] in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then part of [[Poland]].  Separate German Reformed and Lutheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and [[Helvetic Confession]] - joined the "Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Kolomyia]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Przemyśl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After [[World War II]] the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
 After the break up of the [[Soviet Union]], short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. They formed church planting teams to shepherd the forming religious communities.
 The church in [[Odessa]] was the first church to be particularized in the history of the denomination. In 1998, the Ukrainian government granted the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa the 100-year-old historic building that had housed a reformed congregation before the advent of communist restrictions to religious practice. During [[Communist]] times, the building had been seized and turned into a puppet theater. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. Upon regaining possession of the building, the Presbyterian Church renovated it and installed an organ.  Weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. It has become a center for church planters in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref><ref>http://swanson4ukraine.wordpress.com/tag/evangelical-presbyterian-reformed-church-of-odessa/</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organized at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]</ref>

 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' is a [[Christian fundamentalism|conservative]] [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denomination in the [[Calvinism|Reformed tradition]]. It holds to the [[presbyterian polity|presbyterian]] form of [[ecclesiastical polity|church governance]] and to the Reformed theology of the [[Westminster Standards]].<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net www.reformiert-online.net]</ref>
 
 == Origin ==
-The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kiev]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |title=www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617113344/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |archive-date=2013-06-17 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
+The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kyiv]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |title=www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617113344/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |archive-date=2013-06-17 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
 
 == History ==
 It's a little-known fact that the [[Reformation]] came this far eastward, approximately 100 [[Reformed]] churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian-Ukrainian missionaries revitalized the [[Reformed faith]] in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then part of [[Poland]].  Separate German Reformed and Lutheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and [[Helvetic Confession]] - joined the "Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Kolomyia]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Przemyśl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After [[World War II]] the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
@@ -23,7 +23,7 @@
 The Belgorod Christian Clinic is a ministry of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in [[Belgorod-Dnestrovsky]]. The Belgorod Presbyterian Church was the first local church planted by MTW missionaries in Ukraine.
 
 == Missions ==
-The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kiev]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], and [[Kherson]]. The first outreach to [[Western Ukraine]] is taking place through the Lviv church plant. In that beautiful city there is an international, cross-cultural church planting team that is building relationships with people, including through English and mercy ministries.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130415113848/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html |archive-date=2013-04-15 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>
+The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], and [[Kherson]]. The first outreach to [[Western Ukraine]] is taking place through the Lviv church plant. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>
 
 == Reformed Seminary in Ukraine ==
 A reformed seminary The Evangelical Reformed Seminary of Ukraine was opened to train pastors and officers. M.Div classes begun in 2000 with 20 students. In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology classes are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from [[Canada]], the [[United States]], the [[Netherlands]], [[South Africa]] and the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>[http://www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/history www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/history]</ref>

 The Belgorod Christian Clinic is a ministry of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in [[Belgorod-Dnestrovsky]]. The Belgorod Presbyterian Church was the first local church planted by MTW missionaries in Ukraine.
 
 == Missions ==
-The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], and [[Kherson]]. In that beautiful city there is an international, cross-cultural church planting team that is building relationships with people, including through English and mercy ministries.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html |title=Mission to the World MTW Ukraine |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130415113848/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html |archive-date=2013-04-15 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years.  == Reformed Seminary in Ukraine ==
 A reformed seminary The Evangelical Reformed Seminary of Ukraine was opened to train pastors and officers. M.Div classes begun in 2000 with 20 students. In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology classes are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from [[Canada]], the [[United States]], the [[Netherlands]], [[South Africa]] and the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=History – ЕРСУ|url=https://seminary.ersu.org/en/history/|access-date=2021-12-31|language=en-US}}</ref>

--- 
+++ 
@@ -12,18 +12,18 @@
 The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' is a [[Christian fundamentalism|conservative]] [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denomination in the [[Calvinism|Reformed tradition]]. It holds to the [[presbyterian polity|presbyterian]] form of [[ecclesiastical polity|church governance]] and to the Reformed theology of the [[Westminster Standards]].<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net www.reformiert-online.net]</ref>
 
 == Origin ==
-The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kyiv]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |title=www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617113344/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |archive-date=2013-06-17 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
+The '''Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Ukraine''' (EPCU) was recognised as an independent national denomination on April 16, 2008 in [[Odesa|Odesa, Ukraine]].  At of the time of organisation, the denomination had one presbytery comprising three particularised churches and 8 mission churches. As of 2012 the Evangelical Presbyterian Church has 12 churches and missions in various parts of [[Ukraine]]. The EPCU was started by missionaries of the [[Presbyterian Church in America]] in the early 1990s. Holy Trinity Presbyterian Church in [[Kyiv]] has been the largest congregation. There are congregations in 9 various cities.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |title=www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617113344/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Welcome.html |archive-date=2013-06-17 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
 
 == History ==
 It's a little-known fact that the [[Reformation]] came this far eastward, approximately 100 [[Reformed church|Reformed]] churches existed between 1570 - 1590. In the 1930s Canadian-Ukrainian missionaries revitalized the [[Reformed faith]] in Western [[Ukraine]] which was then part of [[Poland]].  Separate German Reformed and Lutheran communities - the Evangelical Church of the Augsburg and [[Helvetic Confession]] - joined the "Union of Reformed Communities". Before the invasion of the [[Red Army]], there were 35 churches in 5 districts and approximately 3,000 members in cities like [[Kolomyia]], [[Lviv]], [[Rivne]], [[Przemyśl]], [[Stepan]]. The Ukrainian Evangelical Reformed Church had 18 ordained pastors. After [[World War II]] the [[Communist]] regime destroyed much of this work.<ref>[http://www.erpco.org.ua/?page_id=140 www.erpco.org.ua/?]</ref>
 
 After the break up of the [[Soviet Union]], short term PCA mission teams began working in various Ukrainian cities. They formed church planting teams to shepherd the forming religious communities.
-The church in [[Odessa]] was the first church to be particularized in the history of the denomination. In 1998, the Ukrainian government granted the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odessa the 100-year-old historic building that had housed a reformed congregation before the advent of communist restrictions to religious practice. During [[Communist]] times, the building had been seized and turned into a puppet theater. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. Upon regaining possession of the building, the Presbyterian Church renovated it and installed an organ.  Weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. It has become a center for church planters in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]{{Dead link|date=January 2022 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Evangelical Presbyterian Reformed Church of Odessa|url=https://swanson4ukraine.wordpress.com/tag/evangelical-presbyterian-reformed-church-of-odessa/|access-date=2021-12-31|website=building in the borderland|language=en}}</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organized at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]{{Dead link|date=January 2022 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
+The church in [[Odesa]] was the first church to be particularized in the history of the denomination. In 1998, the Ukrainian government granted the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Odesa the 100-year-old historic building that had housed a reformed congregation before the advent of communist restrictions to religious practice. During [[Communist]] times, the building had been seized and turned into a puppet theater. The 1,300 square foot building was built in 1898, and seats 500. Upon regaining possession of the building, the Presbyterian Church renovated it and installed an organ.  Weekly attendance is more than 100 and expanded in five various cities. It has become a center for church planters in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]{{Dead link|date=January 2022 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Evangelical Presbyterian Reformed Church of Odesa|url=https://swanson4ukraine.wordpress.com/tag/evangelical-presbyterian-reformed-church-of-odessa/|access-date=2021-12-31|website=building in the borderland|language=en}}</ref> The Evangelical Presbyterian Church was officially organized at a celebration service on April 16, 2008 in the Ukrainian city of Odesa.<ref>[http://www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today www.leben.us/volume-01-issue-3/164-the-odessa-church-today]{{Dead link|date=January 2022 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
 
 The Belgorod Christian Clinic is a ministry of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in [[Belgorod-Dnestrovsky]]. The Belgorod Presbyterian Church was the first local church planted by MTW missionaries in Ukraine.
 
 == Missions ==
-The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kyiv]], [[Odessa]], [[Lviv]], and [[Kherson]]. The first outreach to [[Western Ukraine]] is taking place through the Lviv church plant. In that beautiful city there is an international, cross-cultural church planting team that is building relationships with people, including through English and mercy ministries.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html |title=Mission to the World MTW Ukraine |access-date=2013-03-15 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130415113848/http://www.mtwukraine.org/Mission_to_the_World__Ukraine/Contact_us.html |archive-date=2013-04-15 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The goal is to have 44 [[Presbyterian]] churches in the next 15 years. The biggest goal to become financial self-supporting.<ref>[http://www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html www.burnhamsnapshots.com/Our_ministry.html]</ref>
+The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kyiv]], [[Odesa]], [[Lviv]], and [[Kherson]]. The first outreach to [[Western Ukraine]] is taking place through the Lviv church plant. In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology classes are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from [[Canada]], the [[United States]], the [[Netherlands]], [[South Africa]] and the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=History – ЕРСУ|url=https://seminary.ersu.org/en/history/|access-date=2021-12-31|language=en-US}}</ref>

-*[http://www.erpco.org.ua/ Odessa Presbyterian Church]

In the Evangelical Reformed Seminary theology classes are taught by qualified teachers and guest professors from [[Canada]], the [[United States]], the [[Netherlands]], [[South Africa]] and the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=History – ЕРСУ|url=https://seminary.ersu.org/en/history/|access-date=2021-12-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
-The founder of the seminary is Dr. Clay Quarterman. The current president is Rev. Erik van Alten.<ref>[http://www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/faculty www.ersu.org/en/about-ersu/faculty]</ref>
+The founder of the seminary is Dr. Clay Quarterman. The current president is Rev.  == Missions ==
-The church has mission churches in various cities, and has plans to plant many new churches in the coming years. There are mission teams in [[Kyiv]], [[Odesa]], [[Lviv]], and [[Kherson]]. The first outreach to [[Western Ukraine]] is taking place through the Lviv church plant.
